channel.title: Resources on Digital.gov
channel.description: Recent content in Resources on Digital.gov

item.title: Requirements for achieving efficiency, transparency, and innovation through reusable and open source software
item.description: Learn how Federal Source Code Policy supports reuse and public access to custom-developed federal source code.

item.title: California wildfires guidance for U.S. government websites and social media
item.description: Addressing web and digital communications related to the California wildfires.

item.title: An introduction to podcasts
item.description: Explore the basics of launching a podcast and determine if creating a podcast is right for your agency.

item.title: An introduction to data visualization
item.description: Use data visualization to communicate insights, tell a story, and share actionable information.

item.title: An introduction to decommissioning sites
item.description: Learn how to decommission a federal agency website when it no longer provides value or meets user needs.

item.title: Requirements for transforming federal customer experience and service delivery
item.description: Learn how to strengthen customer experience and service delivery within your federal agency.

item.title: An introduction to multilingual glossaries
item.description: Learn how to use multilingual glossaries to share common translations and contribute to consistent communication across government.

item.title: Hurricane Helene guidance for U.S. government websites and social media
item.description: Addressing web and digital communications related to Hurricane Helene

item.title: How to conduct a project reflection
item.description: Use this template, shared at the 2024 Spring Community Summit, to improve your own service delivery.

item.title: How to transition a team off of a project
item.description: Use this template, shared at the 2024 Spring Community Summit, to improve your own service delivery.

item.title: Requirements for strengthening the federal government's commitment to digital accessibility
item.description: Learn how to implement Section 508, and strengthen and maintain your agency’s commitment to digital accessibility.

item.title: Administration Actions on AI
item.description: Steps to promote the safe, secure, and trustworthy use of AI. Includes: progress reports, federal agency use cases, and voluntary private sector commitments, as well as the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights, NIST AI Risk Management Framework, National AI R&D Strategic Plan, and National AI Research Resource (NAIRR) Pilot.

item.title: An introduction to customer experience
item.description: Understand what customer experience (CX) is and how to leverage customer feedback and analytics to enhance the public’s experience when interacting with government services.

item.title: Requirements for the registration and use of .gov domains in the federal government
item.description: Learn how to implement the DOTGOV Online Trust in Government Act and understand how to register federal internet domain names.

item.title: Requirements for improving access to services for people with limited English proficiency (LEP)
item.description: Learn how to strengthen and improve meaningful language access for all people in the U.S., regardless of the language they speak.

item.title: An introduction to the Digital Experience Council
item.description: The Digital Experience (DX) Council plays a critical role in coordinating governmentwide efforts and assisting agencies in delivering digital experiences that meet the public’s needs and expectations.

item.title: Social media cyber-vandalism toolkit
item.description: Cyber-vandalism presents a serious challenge to online-based communication tools. This resource provides information for agency practitioners to prepare for, recover from, and respond to cyber-vandalism.

item.title: Requirements for improving the management of federal programs and projects
item.description: Learn how to implement the Program Management Improvement Accountability Act to deliver better websites and digital services.

item.title: Overview of the Privacy Act of 1974 (2020 Edition)
item.description: This overview, prepared by the Department of Justice’s Office of Privacy and Civil Liberties (OPCL), covers various provisions of the Privacy Act, as addressed by court decisions in cases involving the Act’s disclosure prohibition, its access and amendment provisions, and its agency record-keeping requirements.

item.title: An introduction to working with social media influencers
item.description: Learn how to partner with social media influencers and design, implement, and measure an influencer program.

item.title: The CDC Clear Communication Index
item.description: The CDC Clear Communication Index is a research-based tool to help you develop and assess public communication materials.

item.title: Fifteen Plays of Our Contact Center Approach
item.description: Following relevant laws, policies, and guidance, the Contact Center Center of Excellence (CoE) developed a 15-play Playbook for federal agencies that are looking to modernize and optimize their contact centers. While not every play will apply to your agency, these plays will get you started.

item.title: Performance.gov
item.description: Performance.gov provides the public, agencies, members of Congress, academics, and the media a view into the progress underway to improve federal government performance and accountability to the American public.

item.title: TechFAR Hub
item.description: Understand how to buy, build, and deliver modern digital services while staying on the correct side of compliance with the TechFAR Hub.

item.title: FY 23 Governmentwide Section 508 Assessment
item.description: Report: Assessment of compliance with Section 508 requirements.

item.title: M-24-08 Strengthening Digital Accessibility and the Management of Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act
item.description: Provides requirements and recommendations to support agency integration of digital accessibility into their missions and operations, helping government technology and information resources better serve a diverse public and federal workforce.

item.title: An introduction to content
item.description: Best practices for creating clear, useful, digital content for federal websites and digital services.

item.title: An introduction to web security
item.description: Guidance on meeting security requirements for federal websites.

item.title: An introduction to privacy
item.description: Introductory guidance on implementing privacy protections for users of federal websites.

item.title: An introduction to analytics
item.description: Learn how to set performance goals, and identify specific KPIs and targets to measure and meet them, using web analytics.

item.title: Moving to .gov
item.description: If you’re moving to .gov from another top-level domain, like .com, .org, or .us, here are some best practices to help you plan that transition.

item.title: PlainLanguage.gov
item.description: A resource to help federal employees write in plain language and comply with the Plain Writing Act of 2010.

item.title: An introduction to structured content
item.description: Publishing content as modular pieces of information that are tagged with machine-readable descriptions can transform how people find, understand, share, use, and reuse government information.

item.title: Executive Order on the Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence
item.description: Establishes new standards for AI safety and security, protects Americans’ privacy, advances equity and civil rights, stands up for consumers and workers, promotes innovation and competition, advances American leadership around the world, and more.

item.title: An introduction to ATOs
item.description: What is an Authorization to Operate? Before you use software in government, you need to make sure it is allowed. You should know what an ATO is, and when you need one.

item.title: An introduction to security and privacy controls
item.description: What do the control families of NIST 800-53 mean? Here’s an overview of the control families that create the foundation of federal security compliance.

item.title: An introduction to trust
item.description: Guidance on how to build government websites that people can trust.

item.title: An introduction to search
item.description: Learn why search functionality is an important component of federal websites, and discover how to add a search function to your website.

item.title: Federal IT Dashboard
item.description: Enables the government and the public to understand the value of their federal IT portfolios, manage the health of their IT investments, and make better IT planning decisions.

item.title: Office of Personnel Management: Office of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility
item.description: OPM’s governmentwide DEIA policies, guidance, and strategic plans, presidential executive orders, federal personnel programs, and frequently asked questions.

item.title: An introduction to design
item.description: How to design government websites that meet customer needs, work well on any device, and follow federal web requirements.

item.title: Making the big move: Search in support of federal web modernization
item.description: In this special report, we discuss a website redesign’s nine phases and their impact on search.

item.title: National Artificial Intelligence Research and Development Strategic Plan (PDF, 861 KB, 56 pages) 2023 Update
item.description: A report by the Select Committee on Artificial Intelligence of the National Science and Technology Council.

item.title: Introduction to translation technology
item.description: What is translation technology? This introductory resource will help you understand how and when to use translation technology to provide meaningful access for people with limited English proficiency.

item.title: An introduction to plain language
item.description: Understand how and why to use plain language on government websites and other digital services

item.title: An introduction to design systems
item.description: If your organization needs to ensure compliance with a design standard or align to a brand, a design system can help you achieve those goals more easily than building a site from scratch. Learn how a design system can help you and what you need to know to get started.

item.title: M-23-10: The Registration and Use of .gov Domains in the Federal Government
item.description: Provides guidance to all federal agencies on the acceptable use and registration of Internet domain names as required by the DOTGOV Online Trust in Government Act of 2020.

item.title: Introduction to QR codes
item.description: What is a QR code and how can you create one? What are some alternatives to using QR codes? This introductory resource will help you explore your options.

item.title: Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR)
item.description: The primary regulation for use by all executive agencies in their acquisition of supplies and services with appropriated funds. The FAR also contains standard solicitation provisions and contract clauses and the various agency FAR supplements.

item.title: Blueprint for an AI Bill of rights
item.description: From the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights is a set of five principles and associated practices to help guide the design, use, and deployment of automated systems to protect the rights of the American public in the age of artificial intelligence.

item.title: Find Your Section 508 Program Manager
item.description: Agency Section 508 Program Managers (PMs) are your first point of contact for questions about IT accessibility.

item.title: Tabular Comparison of the Previous FAR Text Against the 2021 Update
item.description: These FAR Council updates are effective as of September 10, 2021.

item.title: Integrating Accessibility into Agency Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility (DEIA) Implementation Plans
item.description: Guidance on implementing Executive Order (14035) on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility in the Federal Workforce; specifically, elements of the Accessibility Roadmap outlined in the Government-wide DEIA Strategic Plan.

item.title: Accessibility Requirements Tool (ART)
item.description: ART is a multifaceted tool that offers interactive, step-by-step guidance on how to determine applicable accessibility requirements.

item.title: Federal Acquisition Regulation Subpart 39.2 - Information and Communication Technology
item.description: This subpart implements section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (29 U.S.C. 794 d), and the Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board’s (U.S. Access Board) information and communication technology (ICT) accessibility standards at 36 CFR 1194.1.

item.title: Lessons from the 2021 Federal Plain Language Report Card
item.description: This event recap highlights best practices, a short case study video, and examples of federal web content that received both high and low scores in the 2021 Plain Language Report Card.

item.title: Executive Order 14058: Transforming Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery to Rebuild Trust in Government
item.description: A more simple, seamless, and secure customer experience for the American public.

item.title: Web Analytics Playbook
item.description: Use these plays to help strategize how your team can most effectively use web analytics for your website and target audience.

item.title: Multilingual Huddle: Designing for Translation
item.description: In this webinar, Laura Godfrey and Fedora Braverman share tips for translating content in the digital context.

item.title: How to Present Like a Pro
item.description: Wendy Wagner-Smith of the Small Business Administration (SBA) shares her tips and tricks for presenting virtually.

item.title: DOTGOV Online Trust in Government Act of 2020
item.description: Title IX of Public Law No. 116-260, §§ 901-907 (DOTGOV Act of 2020), which outlines responsibilities, authorities, duties, strategies, and requirements related to the process of creating top-level .gov domains, authorizes the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to manage the domain registration process for federal, state, local, tribal, and territorial governments.

item.title: How to Build an Analytics Strategy
item.description: A case study using Digital.gov as an example of how to assess, report, and take action using web analytics as part of an analytics strategy.

item.title: Deceptive Design: How to Identify and Combat Consequence Design
item.description: Consequence design is part of everyday life. Techniques like “deceptive patterns” and “hostile design” trick people into taking unintended actions — learn how to prevent them from sneaking into our design work.

item.title: Guide to Robotic Process Automation
item.description: Configure bots to execute repetitive tasks to save users from performing mundane tasks repeatedly for the same process.

item.title: Privacy-Preserving Collaboration Using Cryptography
item.description: In conjunction with her May 2020 presentation, Dr. Emily Shen outlines her work on Secure multi-party computation (MPC), a type of cryptography that allows parties to jointly analyze their data without disclosing it.

item.title: How to Test Websites for Accessibility
item.description: Use both manual and automated testing methods to create accessible websites.

item.title: Executive Guide to Federal IT Accessibility
item.description: Guidance to help federal agencies improve accessibility to increase compliance with federal policy.

item.title: Foundations of Agile, Part I
item.description: 18F’s Alan Atlas and Alan Brouilette cover the fundamentals of Agile.

item.title: Foundations of Agile, Part II
item.description: 18F’s Alan Atlas and Alan Brouilette cover the fundamentals of Agile.

item.title: 18F Research Guidelines
item.description: Covers the basic principles research: informing and getting consent, and managing personally identifiable information (PII)

item.title: Addressing Barriers to User-Centered Design
item.description: An overview of the most common barriers and how federal agencies might address them.

item.title: Managing Research Projects Remotely
item.description: Best practices for distributed teams.

item.title: The basics of human-centered design in government
item.description: How the Lab at OPM drives innovation through design education

item.title: Stakeholder and User Interview Checklist
item.description: Key interview moments and how to navigate them.

item.title: Usability Testing with Steve Krug
item.description: Get started making usability fixes to your website or product.

item.title: U.S. Web Design System
item.description: A design system for the federal government that makes it easier to build accessible, mobile-friendly government websites for the American public.

item.title: Revised 508 Standards Roadmap
item.description: Follow the Revised 508 Standards to ensure your information and communication technology (ICT) is accessible and usable by individuals with disabilities.

item.title: Federal-Compatible Terms of Service Agreements
item.description: Agreements negotiated between the federal government and vendors who offer digital tools and services.

item.title: Content Management Systems Used by Government Agencies
item.description: A list of Content Management Systems (CMS) used by government agencies.

item.title: An introduction to accessibility
item.description: An overview of how to design and deliver accessible digital products and services in the federal government

item.title: M-19-17 Enabling Mission Delivery through Improved Identity, Credential, and Access Management
item.description: This 2019 memorandum sets forth the federal government’s Identity, Credential, and Access Management (ICAM) policy.

item.title: Chief Diversity Officers Executive Council
item.description: Principal interagency forum to implement and sustain a national strategy for diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility across the federal government and position the federal government as a model for DEIA.

item.title: Guidelines for Digital.gov event presenters
item.description: A checklist of requirements for people who are presenting at a Digital.gov event.

item.title: Executive Order 14091
item.description: Further Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities Through the Federal Government

item.title: Department of Homeland Security: Usability Testing Kit
item.description: A resource with four approaches to help federal employees perform usability testing.

item.title: Chief Information Officer (CIO) Handbook
item.description: This handbook aims to give CIOs important information needed to be a technology leader at their respective agency.

item.title: Government-Wide Strategic Plan to Advance Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility in the Federal Workforce
item.description: Five foundational principles lay out key steps agencies can take to strengthen DEIA in their workforce policies, practices, and culture.

item.title: An introduction to GitHub
item.description: Steps for managing website content in GitHub.

item.title: OMB M-20-19
item.description: Harnessing Technology to Support Mission Continuity

item.title: OMB Circular A-11 Section 280: Managing Customer Experience and Improving Service Delivery
item.description: Guidance on how to measure customer experience, including questions on satisfaction and confidence and trust in section 280.7

item.title: Eight Principles of Mobile-Friendliness
item.description: Following these principles will help you make your site more usable and user-friendly.

item.title: An advanced approach to accessibility
item.description: A deeper look at accessibility: what to do, how to do it, and why it matters.

item.title: Guide to the Paperwork Reduction Act
item.description: A plain language guide which answers the most common questions to the PRA.

item.title: Cloud Smart: Federal Cloud Computing Strategy
item.description: Founded on three key pillars of successful cloud adoption—security, procurement, and workforce—the Cloud Smart strategy includes 11 action items from the Chief Information Officers (CIO) Council.

item.title: An Introduction to USWDS 3.0
item.description: A design system for the federal government that makes it easier to build accessible, mobile-friendly government websites for the American public.

item.title: Customer Experience Toolkit
item.description: This Toolkit is intended to help government agencies improve how we deliver services and information to the public.

item.title: Bilingual Glossaries, Dictionaries, and Style Guides
item.description: Multilingual resources to standardize the use of various languages across government.

item.title: Checklist of requirements for federal websites and digital services
item.description: Links to relevant laws, policies, and regulations for federal agencies.

item.title: Required web content and links
item.description: Various policies require you to have certain content—or provide links to content—from specific places on your website.

item.title: 18F Accessibility Guide
item.description: A resource for developing accessible products.

item.title: Accessibility for Teams
item.description: A guide to making products more accessible for everyone.

item.title: OMB Circular A-130
item.description: Managing Information as a Strategic Resource

item.title: Tips for Starting Your Customer Experience Journey
item.description: Low-cost, low-lift actions that any federal employee can take to improve customer experience.

item.title: USWDS Maturity Model
item.description: How to adopt the design system incrementally and design and build better digital experiences.

item.title: An introduction to digital governance
item.description: Learn why governance is essential to digital experience.

item.title: An introduction to federal website standards
item.description: The federal website standards help agencies provide high-quality, consistent digital experiences for everyone.

item.title: An introduction to domain management
item.description: A .gov domain instantly conveys credibility and trustworthiness, and proper domain management practices ensure that your website is secure and accessible.

item.title: Requirements for delivering a digital-first public experience
item.description: Learn how to implement 21st Century IDEA to design and deliver better websites and digital services.

item.title: M-23-07, Update to Transition to Electronic Records
item.description: M-23-07 updates the previous target dates described in M-19-21 to June 24, 2024.

item.title: 18F De-risking Guides
item.description: The Federal Field Guide to De-risk Government Technology offers guidance to federal agencies on how to structure software development teams, write contracts, and oversee agile software activities to reduce risks and improve outcomes for end-users.

item.title: Best Practices for Writing for the Accessible Web
item.description: Tips for making online information accessible for those with auditory and visual needs.

item.title: The website standards
item.description: As defined in 21st Century IDEA, the Design System incorporates federal standards to improve federal websites and digital services.

item.title: Tips for capturing the best data from user interviews
item.description: How to ensure the most useful information makes its way back to your team for further analysis

item.title: How to get started with challenges and prizes
item.description: A knowledge repository that includes case studies of successful challenges and best practices for running challenges of all kinds and even ways to contact experts in different phases of the process.

item.title: How to track performance
item.description: A step-by-step guide to picking metrics and tools for tracking performance on your site.

item.title: 18F Guide to Product Management
item.description: Best practices on doing product management well

item.title: 18F Methods
item.description: A collection of tools that describe how teams can put human-centered design into practice.

item.title: How to Prevent Security Certificates From Expiring During a Lapse in Operations
item.description: These are the steps that people in government can take to avoid having security certificates expire during a lapse in operations.

item.title: Mobile Development Strategies
item.description: The following is a list of the most common mobile development strategies.

item.title: A Guide to Creating Mobile-Friendly Websites
item.description: Based on a recent six-month study, this guide outlines the top five practices needed to improve the mobile-friendliness of federal websites: the optimization of JavaScript, CSS, and images, caching, and pop-ups.

item.title: Connected Government Act
item.description: Resources to help your agency comply with the Connected Government Act.

item.title: Digital Governance Policy Outline
item.description: A template for digital governance policies.

item.title: Style Guides by Government Agencies
item.description: This page is a collection of style guides created by government agencies.

item.title: Top 10 Best Practices for Multilingual Websites
item.description: Ten tips for creating and managing multilingual government websites.

item.title: Government Customer Service Policies & Requirements: 1993 to Present
item.description: A list of government customer service policies and requirements.

item.title: Implementation of the Government Paperwork Elimination Act
item.description: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) provided this guidance to implement the Government Paperwork Elimination Act (GPEA). GPEA required Federal agencies, by October 21, 2003, to allow individuals or entities that deal with the agencies the option to submit information or transact with the agency electronically, when practicable, and to maintain records electronically, when practicable.

item.title: 2012 Digital Government Strategy
item.description: The Digital Government Strategy complements several initiatives aimed at building a 21st century government that works better for the American people.

item.title: Requirements for Accepting Externally Issued Identity Credentials
item.description: This memo dated October 6, 2011, from the Federal CIO to the CIO’s of Executive Departments and Agencies, mandates that agencies are to begin leveraging externally-issued credentials, in addition to continuing to offer federally-issued credentials.

item.title: OMB Final Guidance on Implementing the Plain Writing Act of 2010 (M-11-15)
item.description: Provides final guidance on implementing the Plain Writing Act of 2010 and is designed to promote the goals of the president’s Open Government Initiative.

item.title: OMB Memo on Testing and Simplifying Federal Forms
item.description: View or download the OMB Memo on Testing and Simplifying Federal Forms

item.title: Open Data Policy (M-13-13)
item.description: This Memorandum establishes a framework to help institutionalize the principles of effective information management at each stage of the information’s life cycle to promote interoperability and openness.

item.title: Making Open and Machine Readable the New Default for Government Information
item.description: Openness in government strengthens our democracy, promotes the delivery of efficient and effective services to the public, and contributes to economic growth. As one vital benefit of open government, making information resources easy to find, accessible, and usable can fuel entrepreneurship, innovation, and scientific discovery that improves Americans’ lives and contributes significantly to job creation.

item.title: Guidance for Implementing the Privacy Provisions of the E–Government Act of 2002 (M-03–22)
item.description: This guidance provides information to agencies on implementing the privacy provisions of the E-Government Act of 2002. It addresses privacy protections when Americans interact with their government.

item.title: GOV Domain Registration Process Final Rule
item.description: This final rule provided a new policy for the .gov domain that will be included in the Federal Management Regulation.

item.title: Digital Millennium Copyright Act
item.description: The Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) is a United States copyright law that implements two 1996 treaties of the World Intellectual Property Organization (WIPO).

item.title: U.S. Trademark Law
item.description: United States trademark law is mainly governed by the Lanham Act.

item.title: Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. 3501 et seq.)
item.description: The Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) of 1995 requires that agencies obtain Office of Management and Budget (OMB) approval before requesting most types of information from the public.

item.title: Guidance on the Use of Challenges and Prizes to Promote Open Government
item.description: This guidance calls for the increased use of challenges and prizes to develop new tools and approaches to improve open government, and highlights for agencies policy and legal issues related to the use of prizes and challenges as tools for promoting open government, innovation, and other national priorities.

item.title: Circular A-130 Revised
item.description: Circular A-130 was first issued in December 1985 to meet information resource management requirements that were included in the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) of 1980. Specifically, the PRA assigned responsibility to the OMB Director to develop and maintain a comprehensive set of information resources management policies for use across the Federal government, and to promote

item.title: Quick Reference to Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 2.0 requirements
item.description: This quick reference guide will help you meet Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.0. It is a customizable quick reference to the requirements, success criteria and techniques.

item.title: Guidelines for Secure Use of Social Media
item.description: Guidelines and recommendations for using social media technologies in a manner that minimizes risks are analyzed and presented in this document.

item.title: Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 – Presentation to the 2003 FISSEA Conference
item.description: The head of the agency delegates to the CIO a number of information security responsibilities. The CIO in turn designates a senior agency information security officer.

item.title: Guidelines on Securing Public Web Servers
item.description: The World Wide Web (WWW) is a system for exchanging information over the Internet. At the most basic level, the Web can be divided into two principal components: Web servers, which are applications that make information available over the Internet (in essence, publish information), and Web browsers (clients), which are used to access and display.

item.title: FY 2004 Reporting Instructions for the Federal Information Security Management Act
item.description: This memorandum provides updated instructions for agency reporting under the Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 (FISMA).

item.title: NARA guidance on Managing Web Records
item.description: Managing web records properly is essential to effective web site operations, especially the mitigation of the risks an agency faces by using the web to carry out agency business.

item.title: Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Parts 1220-1238
item.description: Subchapter B of the CFR specifies polices for federal agencies records management programs relating to proper records creation and maintenance, adequate documentation, and records disposition. View Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Parts 1220-1238 Related Links NARA guidance for implementing Section 207(e) of the E-Gov Act NARA guidance on managing web records NARA Bulletin 2014-02 Guidance

item.title: Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule)
item.description: The Rule imposes certain requirements on operators of websites or online services directed to children under 13 years of age, and on operators of other websites or online services that have actual knowledge that they are collecting personal information online from a child under 13 years of age.

item.title: Appendix I to OMB Circular No. A-130 Federal Agency Responsibilities for Maintaining Records About Individuals
item.description: This Appendix describes agency responsibilities for implementing the reporting and publication requirements of the Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a.

item.title: Guidance for Agency Use of Third-Party Websites and Applications
item.description: This Memorandum requires Federal agencies to take specific steps to protect individual privacy whenever they use third-party websites and applications to engage with the public.

item.title: Open Government Directive
item.description: This memorandum is intended to direct executive departments and agencies to take specific actions to implement the principles of transparency, participation, and collaboration set forth in the President’s Memorandum on Transparency and Open Government. This Directive was informed by recommendations from the Federal Chief Technology Officer, who solicited public comment through the White House Open

item.title: No FEAR Act
item.description: The No FEAR Act requires a Federal agency to post on its public Web site summary statistical data pertaining to complaints of employment discrimination filed under 29 CFR part 1614 by employees, former employees and applicants for employment.

item.title: Guidance on President’s Management Agenda Scorecard Meetings
item.description: This memorandum provides Resource Management Offices and PMA Initiative Leads with instructions for preparing for the quarterly PMA scorecard meetings to discuss agencies’ status and progress in implementing the PMA for the period January 1, 2008 through March 31, 2008.

item.title: Social Media, Web-Based Interactive Technologies, and the Paperwork Reduction Act
item.description: This memo clarifies when and how the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995 (the PRA) applies to federal agency use of social media and web-based interactive technologies.

item.title: Executive Order 13571 — Streamlining Service Delivery and Improving Customer Service
item.description: Executive Order 13571 requires agencies that provide significant services directly to the public to identify and survey their customers, establish service standards and track performance against those standards, and benchmark customer service performance against the best in business.

item.title: M-11-24 Implementing Executive Order 13571 on Streamlining Service Delivery and Improving Customer Service
item.description: Memo M-11-24 is guidance to Implement Executive Order 13571.

item.title: M-10-22 Guidance for Online Use of Web Measurement and Customization Technologies
item.description: On January 21, 2009, the President issued a memorandum calling for the establishment of “a system of transparency, public participation, and collaboration.” The memorandum required an Open Government Directive to be issued by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), instructing “executive departments and agencies to take specific actions implementing the principles

item.title: M-11-26 New Fast-Track Process for Collecting Service Delivery Feedback Under the Paperwork Reduction Act
item.description: The new Paperwork Reduction Act Fast Track Process will allow agencies to obtain timely feedback on service delivery while ensuring that the information collected is useful and minimally burdensome for the public, as required by the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1995.

item.title: U.S. Access Board Section 508 Standards
item.description: The Section 508 Standard for Electronic and Information Technology requires that when a federal agency shares information digitally, individuals with disabilities seeking information or services from a federal agency, must have access to and be able to use the information and data, unless an undue burden would be imposed on the agency.

item.title: Plain Writing Act of 2010
item.description: The law requires that federal agencies provide clear communication about government information and services for the public.

item.title: Federal Plain Language Guidelines
item.description: The Plain Language Action and Information Network (PLAIN) put together these federal guidelines to help implement the Plain Language Act of 2010.

item.title: 2012 Digital Government Strategy
item.description: The 2012 Digital Government Strategy mission drives agencies, and the need to deliver better services to customers at a lower cost.

item.title: E-Gov Act of 2002
item.description: The purpose of the E-Government Act of 2002 includes improving the management and promotion of electronic government services and processes, and establishing a framework of measures that require using Internet-based information technology to improve citizen access to government information and services.

item.title: Freedom of Information Act Memo 2009
item.description: The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) is the law that gives anyone the right to access information from the federal government. It is often described as the law that keeps citizens in the know about their government.

item.title: Open Opportunities Task Creator Toolkit
item.description: The step-by-step task creation process for Open Opportunities.

item.title: 10 Tips for Creating the Perfect Open Opportunity Task
item.description: Ten tips for creating tasks in Open Opportunities on USAJOBS.

item.title: Plain Language Web Writing Tips
item.description: Help your readers complete their tasks with these Plain Language writing tips.

item.title: Inventory.data.gov Guide
item.description: Introduction Features Using inventory.data.gov Creating a User Account Using inventory.data.gov to manage datasets Adding a Dataset Exporting Data.json Automating data.json downloads by agencies Dataset Hosting Webinar on inventory.data.gov Introduction Inventory.data.gov is a data management tool established in 2013 by the Data.gov Program Management Office (PMO) in what is now the Technology Transformation Service of the

item.title: Social Media Cyber-Vandalism Toolkit
item.description: Cyber-vandalism presents a serious challenge to online-based communication tools. This document provides guidance and security practices to federal, state, and local government employees. Suggestions and resources prepare users to respond to cyber-hijacking.

item.title: How to Get Your Open Data on Data.gov
item.description: Find out below how federal, federal geospatial, and non-federal data is funneled to Data.gov and how you can get your data federated on Data.gov for greater discoverability and and impact.

item.title: Improving the Accessibility of Social Media in Government
item.description: Government agencies are increasingly using social media to engage with citizens, share information and deliver services more quickly and effectively than ever before. But as social content, data and platforms become more diverse, agencies have a responsibility to ensure these digital services are accessible to all citizens, including people with disabilities.

item.title: Federal Social Media Accessibility Toolkit Hackpad
item.description: The following contains the shared document for the development of the Social Media Policy Toolkit, a shared service of the Federal Social Media Community of Practice lead by teams including The Department of Labor’s Office of Disability Employment Policy.

item.title: Sample Position Descriptions for Digital Government Jobs
item.description: Use and customize these sample position descriptions to hire your own digital gov team. Position descriptions, as defined by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), include an official series, title, and grade based on the results of a classification determination. Accessibility Web Development and Accessibility Specialist (Word document, 22 KB, 1 page, September 2012) Analytics

item.title: Spanish Language Style Guide and Glossaries: Spanish Health Care Terms in the United States
item.description: A list of common English health care and medical terms, and their Spanish translations.

item.title: Spanish Language Style Guide and Glossaries: Internet Resources
item.description: A list of additional Internet resources to help standardize the use of Spanish across government.

item.title: Spanish Language Style Guide and Glossaries: Information Technology Terms
item.description: A list of common English information technology terms, and their Spanish translations.

item.title: Spanish Language Style Guide and Glossaries: Frequently Mistranslated English Terms
item.description: A collection of frequently mistranslated English terms and their equivalent in Spanish.

item.title: Spanish Language Style Guides and Glossaries
item.description: Spanish Language Style Guides are resources for government employees, translators, and communications professionals who work with the government that contains information on grammar and style issues, and glossaries to standardize the use of Spanish across government.

item.title: Open Opportunities
item.description: Open Opportunities is a government wide program offering professional development opportunities and facilitating collaboration and knowledge sharing across the Federal Government.

item.title: Guidelines for Improving Digital Services
item.description: The Digital Services Advisory Group and the Federal Web Managers Council have developed the following guidelines to meet the 6.1 milestone of the Digital Government Strategy. These recommendations apply to all digital services, including Web, mobile, apps, APIs, and online forms. Guidelines Guideline 1: Digital Strategy Integrate your digital presence into your agency’s overall business, communications, and customer experience strategy Guideline 2: Governance,

item.title: Crowdsourcing Toolkit for Federal Agencies
item.description: What is a Challenge? In a challenge, a “seeker” challenges “solvers” to identify a solution to a particular problem, or rewards contestants for accomplishing a goal.

item.title: Guidance for Social Media Providers
item.description: GSA welcomes interest from providers that want to offer, for the federal government’s consideration, social media products that are free of charge. If you are such a provider, please email GSA and include the following information: Explanation of the

item.title: Spanish Language Style Guide and Glossaries: Grammar
item.description: Examples and explanations for words, phrases, acronyms, numbers, punctuation, capitalization, symbols, and more used in Spanish grammar.

item.title: Contact Center Operation and Management
item.description: Many things can impact the service quality, economics, and sustainability of your government contact center. This section provides insight on various aspects of operating and managing a contact center to help you improve its performance.

item.title: Contact Center Technologies
item.description: A contact center is supported by many technologies designed to enhance the customer experience, improve the operating and management efficiency, or lower the overall costs of running a contact center.

item.title: Getting Started with your Contact Center
item.description: This guide provides you with the information to get a governement contact center started

item.title: Contact Center Guidelines
item.description: The Contact Center is no longer viewed as only a center to receive complaints, but as a valued operation in an agency’s strategy to deliver a quality customer experience.

item.title: Usability Starter Kit
item.description: Here are some tools and templates to help you create better user experiences.

item.title: DigitalGov User Experience Program: Test Support
item.description: It’s always best to test a product BEFORE you release it. So the best time to evaluate the usability of a product is as early as possible, including when you are creating wireframes and prototypes. But even if you’ve gone past that point

item.title: DigitalGov User Experience Program: Speaking Opportunities
item.description: The DigitalGov User Experience Program presents to federal audiences by phone, webinar and in person. We cover a variety of topics, including: User Centered Design and Usability Best (and Worst) Practices on Government Websites How to Improve Federal Digital Services and more Potential audiences include: CIOs

item.title: Fueleconomy.gov – Extended Case Study
item.description: Like any valid business decision, User Experience work should produce results and demonstrable impact. To see a list of screenshots from websites we’ve improved, visit the rest of our Usability Case Studies. Or see a more complete case study below. Case Study: Fueleconomy.gov Mobile Site In December of 2012

item.title: Negotiated Terms of Service Agreements
item.description: The list of free tools that have federal-compatible terms of service agreements.

item.title: Paperwork Reduction Act Fast Track Process
item.description: Protect Your Customer’s Privacy Federal agencies must follow various laws and regulations, including the Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA) and the Privacy Act, when collecting information from the public. You should also be familiar with SORN (Systems of Records Notice), as well as rules around personally identifiable information, and laws that relate to your specific method of feedback collection

item.title: Agency Points of Contact for Federal Compatible Terms of Service Agreements
item.description: The list of cabinet and non-cabinet agency points of contact for the federal-compatible Terms of Service agreements.

item.title: Mobile User Experience Guidelines
item.description: These mobile user experience guidelines were distilled from community feedback about mobile UX practices.

item.title: DigitalGov User Experience Resources
item.description: DigitalGov’s user experience resources provide tools for federal employees on how to make products and services more user-friendly, save money via user research, and create successful experiences.

item.title: Using the do and don'ts table
item.description: What to do and what not to do, that is the question

item.title: Mobile SOW and Developer Qualifications
item.description: Structuring a Statement of Work (SOW) for the development or modification of mobile products should be similar to any SOW your government organization issues for IT products and services.

item.title: Mobile Application Development Program
item.description: Helping agencies plan, develop, test and launch anytime, anywhere, any device mobile products and services for the public. Plan—Build a mobile strategy, see what other agencies have done, use new acquisitions tools to find top mobile developers. Develop—Create great mobile apps and sites

item.title: Web Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)
item.description: The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) documents explain how to make web content more accessible to people with disabilities. Web “content” generally refers to the information in a web page or web application, including: natural information such as text, images, and sounds code or markup that defines structure, presentation, etc. View the Web Accessibility Guidelines
